newsitem.title: USA: Kimberly says Scott deal cut oper income.
newsitem.headline: Kimberly says Scott deal cut oper income.

text.p: Kimberly-Clark Corp Monday reported higher operating and net earnings in the second quarter, despite its merger with Scott Paper Co cutting its operating income by $0.04 a share.

"Operating profit was adversely affected by strategic changes related to the combination of Kimberly-Clark's and Scott Paper Co's away-from-home businesses in North America." a company statement said. "The transition has resulted in lower sales and higher costs, with a negative impact on operating profit in the second quarter equivalent to $0.04 a share."

The company posted an net income of $363.5 million, or $0.65 a share, in the second quarter, compared with $364.7 million, or $0.64 a share the year before. Excluding an extraordinary gain in the second quarter and non-operating items in both years, the company earned $0.60 a share in the second-quarter, compared with $0.56 a share last year.
A First Call consensus estimate of 11 brokers had put the company's earnings at $0.62 a share.

The company's second quarter sales dropped 6.7 percent to $3.1 billion from $3.3 billion. However, Kimberly-Clark said sales exclusive of revenues from businesses sold in the periods dropped about one percent for the quarter.

Sales of personal care products rose 10.6 percent to $1.33 billion in the second quarter, but tissue sales dropped 15.1 percent to $1.63 billion and newsprint and paper sales plummeted 28.5 percent to $176.8 million.

Kimberly-Clark posted a 36.2 percent rise in personal care products' operating profits to $249.3 million in the quarter. Operating profits in tissue-based products, however, dropped 18.3 percent to $206.8 million. The newsprint and paper division's operating profit dropped 30.9 percent to 43.9 million.
Boosted by the strong personal care products' sales and profits, the company's total operating profit rose 1.3 percent to $494.4 from $488.2 million in the second quarter.
On the plus side, the company's operating margin increased to 15.8 percent of sales in the quarter from 14.6 percent a year ago.

"Our personal care business continued to perform very well, with strong volume growth in every region and improved productivity," said chief executive Wayne Sanders in a statement. "We also continued to benefit from our focus on costs reductions and lower interest expense."

Kimberly-Clark's interest expense dropped to $40.0 million for the quarter from $50.5 last year. The company attributed the drop to its paying off debt, which stood at about $1.9 billion at the quarter's end, compared with $2.5 billion last year.
The company said it bought back 5.6 million shares year-to-date, including 600,000 in the second quarter. It added its board has authorized repurchasing 7.8 million more.
Kimberly-Clark's results seemed to disappoint investors Monday: The company's stock dropped 3-11/16 to 47-7/8 in morning trading.
